summary: To provide emergency services with additional information on accessing locations.
description: Access and Entrance Points were field collected. There is no known source available to compare the field collected data, either for spatial location or attribute accuracy. Access points are primarily along the street and represent a point of access to one or more entrances of a building. In some cases, they are also in the interior of a building complex, because of internal fences or gates. In other cases, an access point represents access to an alley or walkway in the rear or side of a building.

summary: Address points were developed to supplement the address information supplied by the CSCL centerline. Some computer aided dispatch systems use address points as the primary source for locating an address.
description: Address points were initially created from data in the Department of City Planning Property Address Directory (PAD) file. Points were created approximately five feet inside building footprints along the correct street frontage. A field collection/verification process was undertaken to validate "multi-valued" addresses contained in the PAD file (i.e. those locations with a range of addresses). Additionally, a statistical sample of PAD single valued addresses was field checked. Approximately 100,000 locations were visited (about 10% of the total).

summary: To provide alternative street names for an address point.
description: The AddressPointLGCs stores addtional local group codes (LGCs) fro address points

summary: FDNY Alarm Box locations.
description: FDNY Alarm Boxes

summary: CSCL minimizes coincident geometry to locations where true coincidence occurs (e.g. bridge decks). Other coincident cases that exist in the LION file (e.g SAF records, coincident on/off highway ramps) have been migrated to the AltSegmentdata table.
description: The AltSegmentData stores table "alternative" data for CSCL centerline, rail, and shoreline segments.

summary: To generate Atomic Polygon-based district hierarchies.
description: Atomic polygons serve as a set of basic building blocks for generating the polygons of many of the district types represented in the CSCL database. Feature classes such as election district, school district, census block, FDNY administrative company, and community district can be dissolved by combining the appropriate fields in atomic polygons.

summary: To depicts the coverage area for each borough: Manhattan, Queens, Bronx, Brooklyn, and Staten Island.
description: Borough is a polygon representation of New York City boroughs.

summary: To share the geographic boundaries of Business Improvement Districts (BIDs)
description: Dataset contains BID Name and geographic boundaries.

summary: CADSOURCEADDRESS was created to store the source records, in their entirety, from the public safety geofiles (for common place records).
description: The CADSOURCEADDRESS file contains the source records from EMSCAD, Starfire, SPRINT, and PCAD.

summary: The Cellular Call Box feature class represents locations of NYPD maintained Call Boxes throughout New York City.
description: The Cellular Call Box feature class is a point representation of NYPD Cellular Call Boxes. The different methods to create the points include: manual location based on Orthophotography, based on field collected XY coordinates or known locations, and automatically using ArcMap functions.

summary: The Centerline file has been maintained as a major component of the Department of City Planning's Geosupport System and has been updated to meet the needs of the public safety agencies for dispatch
description: Centerline is a single line representation of New York City streets containing address ranges and other information such as traffic directions, road types, segment types.

summary: For use by CSCL users to define city limits.
description: A polygon defining the limits of New York City.

summary: CommonPlace is a point feature representation of points of interest throughout New York City. The primary intended purpose of CommonPlace is to help aid dispatch efforts to these points of interest throughout New York City.
description: The CommonPlace points are a compilation of what the different city agencies consider to be a Common Place or Place/Point of Interest. Sources for the data include: - NYPD (Sprint and PCAD) - FDNY (Starfire and EMSCAD) - OEM Hospitals - DCP Special Address File - DoITT - Points of Interest, NYCHA developments, Schools - DPR Parks Properties Points were either loaded from a previously existing point feature class or they were created. The different methods to create the points include: manual location based on Orthophotography, buildings and/or parcels based on an address or known location, automatically using ArcMap functions, or by entering the centerline XY corrdinate of the location from Geosupport.

summary: To create areas that represent major complexes throughout the City.
description: Complex is a polygon representation of New York City complexes including colleges, hospitals, rail yards, parks, commercial centers, and other govermental buildings campuses. Each complex has a corresponding common place point, which must be linked to in order to get relevant information such as name, street code (B7SC), and SAF Type.

summary: Complex intersections can be used to related "generic" street segments with "roadbed" street segments.
description: Complex intersections represent locations where roadbeds intersect with undivided streets or other roadbeds.

summary: This data is supplied to provide map area coverage used by EMSCAD software to determine the location and EMS_Atom of EMS Units based on locations reported via on-board vehicle location (GPS) systems. This map is NOT intended to provide a "pretty" map display used for reporting purposes. It purpose is to cover all areas where a Unit might be reported. Coverage extends beyond the 5 borough area of NYC to account for unit locations outside the area involving mutual aid and transport to or from various medical facilities outside the 5 borough area. Updates and corrections to EMS Atom boundaries in this version are based on data obtained from: a) Atom area paper map set, (Original Atom maps, scanned and georeferenced) b) EMSCAD blockface file data, c) FDNY GIS Review d) Refinement requests by EMS Command. All revisions have been review by FDNY GIS Unit and EMS Command. Final revisions were conducted with EMS Command on April 6, 2009. Final confirmation and data production on April 9, 2009 This dataset was refined by Bowne Mgmnt under the direction of the HP/AVL team through April 2009.
description: EMS_Atoms v4 This is version '4' of the EMS Atoms series. Prepared 2009.04.10 Used in the production of Geofiles for the EMSCAD dispatching system to resolve vehicle locations obtained via GPS location reports. This version provides two levels of enhancement: 1) Updates and corrections to atom boundaries, 2) Edit boundaries to conform to LION 07C geometry (Initial CSCL base data) Refinements were made by Bowne Mgmnt under the direction of the HP/AVL and FDNY GIS team through April 2009.

summary: To provide the location and detailed information of entrance to a building.
description: Entrance Point is a point representation of New York City buildings that are associated with Access Points. The entrance point must be a physical entry at street level (i.e. rooftop entry will not be considered an entrance point). An entrance point does not have a posted address number.

summary: To associate one (or more name) with a CSCL common place point, complex, rail or subway feature.
description: The FeatureName table stores the names of common places an drail names

summary: Hurricane evacuation zone category (1-6) for locations in New York City.
description: New York City's hurricane contingency plans are based on six evacuation zones. Hurricane evacuation zones are areas of the city that may be inundated by storm surge or isolated by storm surge waters. There are six zones, ranked by the risk of storm surge impact, with Zone 1 being the most likely to flood. In the event of a hurricane or tropical storm, residents in these zones may be ordered to evacuate.

summary:
Point features representing locations of LinkNYC kiosks installed in New York City.

Data for update is obtained from NYC Opendata: https://data.cityofnewyork.us/Social-Services/LinkNYC-Locations/s4kf-3yrf
description: LinkNYC is a first-of-its-kind communications network that will replace over 7,500 pay phones across the five boroughs with new structures called Links. Each Link provides superfast, free public Wi-Fi, phone calls, device charging and a tablet for access to city services, maps and directions.

summary: Mileposts are included as part of CSCL to assist in emergency dispatchg to locations along an arterial highway or other location in the City.
description: Mileposts are small signs placed along limited access arterials (highways, bridges, tunnels). They display the actual distance from some reference origin point along the arterial, often the beginning of the arterial.

summary: Provides the ability to serach and find name intersections in the City.
description: The named intersection table associates nodes (intersections) that have names in the City.

summary: Projection areas were created using whole census tracts that were exact subdivisions of New York City's 55 Public Use Microdata Areas (PUMAs). (PUMAs were developed for use with the Census Bureau's Public Use Microdata Samples (PUMS) and are approximations of Community Districts.) Projection areas were not permitted to cross PUMA boundaries. Users need to be cognizant of the reason why these projection areas were created, and the demographic and geographic constraints inherent in how they were configured.
description: These 'Neighborhoods' are in essence projection areas created to project populations at a small area level, from 2000 to 2030. First and foremost, these aggregations were driven by population size in 2000 - projection areas had to have a minimum population of 15,000, because this reduces the error associated with the projected population. This criterion resulted in combinations of neighborhoods that probably would not occur if one were solely designating boundaries of historical neighborhoods. Moreover, the neighborhood names associated with the projection areas are not intended to be definitive.

summary: Nodes are useful for several reasons: 1) Assignment of a value to an intersection (e.g. reference an incident to an intersection, 2) Used to help assign location to other CSCSL datasets (e.g. Virtual Intersections, Special Intersections) and 3) Required for data editing to support Geosupport.
description: Nodes represent the locations of any combination of linear features in CSCL (a topological junction).

summary: The following are non street feature subtypes: 1) Census_block 2) District_Boundary 3) Election_District 4) Other 5) Physical_Non_ST_Feature 6) Pier_Outline 7) School_District
description: NonStreetFeature is a single line representation of non street features. The LION file includes some of these and are identified by Feature Type.

summary: To provide the ownership of line, the type of line, and the level code of line. To assist in emergency dispatch.
description: Rail is a single line representation of New York City railroads containing route and other information.

summary: To depict the location of rail stations with detailed attributes such as subway type, division, line name.
description: RailStation is a point representation of New York City's rail stations.

summary: 1.) Reference markers are positioned approximately every one-tenth of a mile along arterials. 2.) The reference marker panel legends contain up to twelve alphanumeric characters of identifying information, consisting of a NYS DOT route identification code, identifiers of the county/locality, and a reference marker sequencing number. Reference markers are part of CSCL to assist in identifying a location along an arterial highway.
description: Reference markers are small signs that are positioned systematically at points along state-maintained roads and highways. NYS DOT maintains a system of reference markers affixed to posts, walls, railings and other prominent physical features.

summary: The RPL allows an agency that stores data associated with the roadbed model to migrate data to to the generic model of the centerline.
description: The Roadbed Pointer List (RPL) is a table that relates generic segments to roadbed segments in the CSCL centerline.

summary: To properly assign an Election District when a segment is split.
description: The Split Election District Address Table (SEDAT) stores the address range data associated with segments split by Election Districts.

summary: The Segment_LGC table is the entry point for identifying the valid name(s) for a particular street segment.
description: The Segment_LGC table stores the relationship between a centerline, rail, or shoreline segment and its list of local group codes (LGC).

summary: To depict the shoreline of New York City.
description: Shoreline is a single line representation of New York City shorelines.

summary: To disambiguate multiple intersections from one another.
description: The special intersection table store information relating to ambiguous intersections.

summary: To properly assign an Election District when a segment is split.
description: The Special Split Election District Address Table (SEDAT) stores the address range data associated with segments split by Election Districts. The address information is associated with Special Address File records.

summary: To be the sole source for street names for CSCL and the Geosupport System.
description: The StreetName table stores street names. The street name is parsed into seven component parts according to National Emergency Number Association (NENA) standards. In some cases, such as complex roadbed names, it is not possible to parse the street name in a consistent manner.

summary: NENA street types enforced in the pre and post type fields of the StreetName table. The table STREETTYPE exists to equate agency abbreviations to NENA street types
description: The streettype table stores the various City agency values for street types (e.g. Avenue, Boulevard) and their abbreviations.

summary: Subaddress records for New York City added to the Citywide Street Centerline Geodatabase for emergency response and post emergency canvassing operations.
description: The original source was 2015 USPS data purchased from Melissa by NYC Emergency management. This data was geocoded using the Dept. of City Planning’s Geosupport batch geocoding tool (GBAT). All the Melissa records that represented single addresses (apartments or units) were removed.The original USPS Melissa data came with a single field for the “unit” called “SUITE”. The data in SUITE was parsed into the NENA NG911 CLDXF fields (BUILDING, FLOOR, UNIT, ROOM, SEAT, ADDITIONAL_LOC_INFO). The original text in the SUITE field was retained in the SUBADDRESS table field “MELISSA_SUITE”.This data has been updated current to the 2021 USPS Melissa data.

summary: To depict the location of subway lines with detailed attributes such as subway type, division, line name, and route.
description: Subway is a single line representation of the New York City subway system.

summary: To depict the location of subway stations with detailed attributes such as subway type, division, and line name. Each station associates with a street segment for dispatching - this will be enabled via the field SEGMENTID which will link to a single element in the feature class Centerline.
description: SubwayStation is a point representation of New York City subway stations.

summary: To provide the location of tollbooths.
description: Tollbooth is a point representation of New York City's tollboths.

summary: To aid in respodning to incidents in the subway system.
description: Locations of subway system transit booths.

summary: To assit in emergency response.
description: Locations of transit emergency exits.

summary: To provide detailed attributes and locations of MTA and LIRR entrances to assist public safety agencies.
description: Transit Entrance is a point feature class identifying the location of MTA and LIRR entrances.

summary: To represent NYPD virtual intersections.
description: Virtual centerline was created by importing street segments from NYPD PCAD geodatabases where the classes are equal to "VI" or "CPK". These represent centerline geometries that are unique to the police department which may include streets, water features, and other spatial features.

The Department of City Planning (DCP) created Community District Tabulation Areas (CDTAs) to closely approximate the 59 Community Districts of New York City for the purpose of reporting American Community Survey (ACS) data. CDTAs are built by aggregating whole 2020 census tracts.

2020 and 2010 Neighborhood Tabulation Areas (NTAs) are medium-sized statistical geographies for reporting Decennial Census and American Community Survey (ACS). 2020 NTAs are created by aggregating 2020 census tracts and nest within Community District Tabulation Areas (CDTA). NTAs were delineated with the need for both geographic specificity and statistical reliability in mind. Consequently, each NTA contains enough population to mitigate sampling error associated with the ACS yet offers a unit of analysis that is smaller than a Community District.
Equivalency table of NTA Code to NTA Name.
A sectional chart implemented as an overlay to NYC geography used for reference purposes.
Archive of deleted Street Codes.
Valid abbreviations in the last position of a string for Geosupport purposes.
The purpose of this table is to associate features in the linear feature classes with associated intersections (nodes.)
Valid abbreviations in any position of a string other than the last position for Geosupport purposes.
Virtual Intersections that are not considered "real" intersections but may nevertheless be referenced for location purposes.
